description.plain:
Foo Fighters are an American rock band formed in 1995 by former Nirvana drummer Dave Grohl. Originally a solo project by him to overcome the grief of Kurt Cobain’s death, Grohl attracted label interest with his inaugural demo tape.

According to Dave Grohl, the band is named after the UFOs that were reported by Allied aircraft pilots in World War II.

I was reading a lot of books on UFOs. Not only is it a fascinating subject, but there’s a treasure trove of band names in those UFO books! So, since I had recorded the first record by myself, playing all the instruments, but I wanted people to think that it was a group, I figured that FOO FIGHTERS might lead people to believe that it was more than just one guy. Silly, huh?

Following the recording and release of the band’s self-titled debut album, Grohl recruited a full band to perform the songs live.

Foo Fighters have since achieved mainstream critical and commercial success, with nine studio albums (two of which reached #1 on the Billboard charts), twelve Grammy awards, and no signs of slowing down.

On March 25, 2022, drummer Taylor Hawkins died tragically at the age of 50.

songs.full_title: Everlong by Foo Fighters
songs.title: Everlong

description.plain:
The second single from 1997’s The Colour and the Shape. “Everlong” was penned by Dave Grohl during his split with his first wife, photographer Jennifer Youngblood.

The divorce left him alone, and essentially homeless since she kicked him out of the house. To add insult to injury, the Foo Fighters weren’t doing as well as he envisioned, and his fellow band members were close to quitting. Right as he was about to bottom out, he returned home to Virginia for Christmas 1996 and wrote down the lyrics to this simple little ballad about falling in love with a new woman in a span of 45 minutes. It did well enough to keep the band together and get his life back on track. In Grohl’s words:

That song’s about a girl that I’d fallen in love with and it was basically about being connected to someone so much, that not only do you love them physically and spiritually, but when you sing along with them you harmonize perfectly.

The song has since been immortalized by Grohl’s stripped down and emotional live renditions. It usually finishes concerts (especially because its heartfelt tone contrasts too much with the rest of the setlist).

It is notable for being famous talk show host David Letterman’s favorite song, to the point where FF rescheduled their tour to play on his first show back from heart surgery, and was the last song played on the very last show Letterman hosted before retiring.

It was featured in the rhythm games Guitar Hero: World Tour and Rock Band 2, both released in 2008.

songs.full_title: My Hero by Foo Fighters
songs.title: My Hero

description.plain:
Grohl has claimed he didn’t have any rockstar rolemodels growing up. This song is a tribute to those he did look up to: the everyday people.
The sentiment on this track is simple. You don’t have to be rich, or famous or successful to do something good or heroic.
As with many Foo Fighters songs, fans have tried to appropriate the lyrics to Nirvana frontman, Kurt Cobain, but Dave insists that they refer only to the average man on the street. Whatever the case may be, “My Hero” was still a top 10 rock smash.

songs.full_title: All My Life by Foo Fighters
songs.title: All My Life

description.plain:
“All My Life” is a song by the American alternative rock band Foo Fighters, released as the first single from their fourth album, One by One.

Dave Grohl said that the song was quite sexual in nature. He told Q Magazine

That song is a little dirty. I’m very fond of giving oral sex to women…"

He also noted that the band had wanted a heavier sounding song to appear as a single.

The song won a Grammy Award for Best Hard Rock Performance and spent ten straight weeks at #1 on the Hot Rock chart.

songs.full_title: Best of You by Foo Fighters
songs.title: Best of You

description.plain:
This is a record that had half the world turning up their stereos and bouncing around the room, as Dave Grohl inspires us to do better. The word “best” is repeated over 40 times in this manic four minutes. But there aren’t enough superlatives available to describe the feeling in your stomach when the first few words are sung.



And yet while it became an anthem, once the band did their first version they put it away, feeling it was not up to their standards. Then manager John  Silva felt its absence, and they were forced to do some more work on it.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VCmi_xLoH7Q

Dave said the song had inspiration from playing in the John Kerry presidential campaign, “so I started writing all these songs about breaking away from the things that confine you. ”

songs.full_title: Learn to Fly by Foo Fighters
songs.title: Learn to Fly

description.plain:
In Dave Grohl’s own words:

[“Learn to Fly” is] about the search for some sort of inspiration, the search for signs of life that will make you feel alive. It’s actually one of my least favourite songs on the record.

Musically, “Learn To Fly” is a little less loud than some of the band’s back catalog, and the chorus is more catchy than crazy. It was the first Foo Fighters track to chart on Billboard’s Hot 100, all the way to #19, and it was #1 overall on Billboard’s Hot Alternative Songs list.

The drug-induced disaster flight of a video is probably as famous as the song it accompanies. It won the Grammy Award for “Best Short Form Music Video” in 2001.  The many faces of the band and the Tenacious D cameo are in-flight entertainment at its best.

songs.full_title: The Sky Is a Neighborhood by Foo Fighters
songs.title: The Sky Is a Neighborhood

description.plain:
“The Sky Is A Neighborhood,” a track about life’s hardships, is the second single release from their 2017 album, Concrete and Gold.

Prior to its official release, it was performed in May 2017 at an Acoustic 4 A Cure charity show in San Francisco, which benefitted UCSF Benioff Children’s Hospital’s pediatric cancer wing. Frontman Dave Grohl introduced the song, saying:

I figured on the way up here, I thought, ‘Fuck it, let’s play a new song, man, let’s do something nobody’s heard.’ We’ve never played this song in front of anybody.

songs.full_title: Run by Foo Fighters
songs.title: Run

description.plain:
“Run” tells of an escape from a dream-like stupor with vaguely political themes. It is unique among Foo Fighters music in that it has a heavier sound than the norm.

The track marks the band’s first piece of music to be released since their brief ‘indefinite hiatus’ after their 2015 EP Saint Cecilia.

“Run” was released on June 1, 2017 with a video clip featuring the band in old age make-up running amok in an oppressive retirement home. It was directed by Dave Grohl.



“Run” won a Grammy Award for Best Rock Song at the 2018 Grammys held on Jan. 28, 2018.

songs.full_title: Times Like These by Foo Fighters
songs.title: Times Like These

description.plain:
“Times Like These” is the second single off One By One, and a song with much symbolism regarding that album’s production.

After the early unsuccessful recording sessions, Dave Grohl decided the band had to take a break, and accepted an invitation to play drums for Queens of the Stone Age. However, at a certain point he missed the Foo Fighters, and wrote “Times Like These” to express how “the band disappearing for those two or three months and me feeling like I wasn’t entirely myself.”

It was the first of three new compositions brought to the re-recording of One by One in Grohl’s Virginia home studio, along with “Low” and “Disenchanted Lullaby”.

songs.full_title: Big Me by Foo Fighters
songs.title: Big Me

description.plain:
“Big Me” is a heartfelt ballad written for Dave Grohl’s first wife, Jennifer Youngblood.

It’s best remembered for the music video spoofing Mentos commercials, which Grohl felt it fit as “Big Me” is “this short, tongue-in-cheek, ridiculously candy-coated pop tune”. The video’s success made the band stop playing it for 10 years, given fans would throw Mentos and it felt like a stoning as “Those little … things are like pebbles — they hurt.”

songs.full_title: These Days by Foo Fighters
songs.title: These Days

description.plain:
Dave Grohl said to Q magazine that he thinks this meditation on heartbreak and loss, “might be the best song I’ve ever written.” Rolling Stone liked it too, naming it their fourth best single of 2011.

The Wayne Isham directed video was shot during the Foo Fighters' Australian and New Zealand tour.

In 2015, Grohl told Entertainment Weekly that this is one of the most memorable songs he’s ever written. “Every night I sing it, I still get choked up,” he said.

songs.full_title: I'll Stick Around by Foo Fighters
songs.title: I’ll Stick Around

description.plain:
One of the few songs written on the eve of recording Foo Fighters, “I’ll Stick Around” is defined by Dave Grohl as “a very negative song about feeling you were violated or deprived”. It was widely rumoured as a potshot on Kurt Cobain’s widow Courtney Love, but now Dave doesn’t even try to hide:

“I don’t think it’s any secret that ‘I’ll Stick Around’ is about Courtney.” I’ve denied it for fifteen years, but I’m finally coming out and saying it. Just read the fucking words!"

For the music video, Devo singer Gerald Casale was brought in to revive the weird spirit of his band’s work.

songs.full_title: Rescued by Foo Fighters
songs.title: Rescued

description.plain:
The lead single from the Foo Fighters 11th album, “Rescued” is about trying to move on, and needing a rescue. The song was written shortly after drummer Taylor Hawkins’ untimely passing and takes inspiration from that feeling.
Dave Grohl also fills in for the drums on this track, as well as the rest of the album.

songs.full_title: Under You by Foo Fighters
songs.title: Under You

description.plain:
“Under You” serves as the seconds single from “But Here We Are”, Foo Fighters' 11th album.

The song continues the album’s trend of emulating part of the classic Foo Fighters sound, and lyrically tackles the band recovering from the loss of their beloved drummer Taylor Hawkins and how life feels without him.

songs.full_title: Arrows by Foo Fighters
songs.title: Arrows

description.plain:
“Arrows” is Concrete and Gold seventh track. As Dave Grohl said:

It happened at the perfect time. I was inspired by what was going on with our country—politically, personally, as a father, an American and a musician. There was a lot to write about.

So, the song could talk about a refugee, as she “Had arrows in her eyes, fear where her heart should be, war in her mind.”

songs.full_title: Aurora by Foo Fighters
songs.title: Aurora

description.plain:
Do you remember “Aurora”? Arguably the Foo Fighters' greatest non-single of all-time!

In Dave Grohl’s own words:

‘Aurora’ is definitely one of my favourite songs that we’ve ever come up with. Lyrically, it’s just kind of a big question mark, but the words sound good and it’s a nostalgic look back at Seattle and the life I once had. That song actually questions the meaning of life, probably. It’s probably the heaviest thing I’ve ever written.

In addition, Jeff Apter wrote in his biography of Grohl, The Dave Grohl Story, that this song was also inspired by the death of his grandmother.
